text: Thank you. Good morning, Your Worship and Councillors. I wasn't actually aware that the AGM had been deferred for 12 months. I wasn't sure whether it was going to be held.  at all later in the year, but if that's the case, if it's been deferred for 12 months, then we'll work on that timeline. What we've been trying to look here, really, is to avoid every council having to go through what is quite a lengthy, complex process, particularly if we are just looking to use a macro, and I think it might be different if you're coming up with a completely new name for your council. So, we did some work with Simpson Grierson and got some advice on some options from them,  but consider that this is a matter that should be raised by LGNZ with DIA to look at those options and find a solution for local government. So, just looking to keep things simple. Obviously, the hope now is that we can go to a Zone 2 meeting to get support there rather than having to go round up and round up some other council support.  which was going to be the case because of a tight timeframe if we had been heading for this year's LGNZ AGM. And I think that with our emphasis on protecting our elite soils, this doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that. It doesn't do that.  And I'm really, really concerned that there's been no provision made for a more dense lot of housing within this 420 acres. In fact, there's no commentary on it at all.  The thing that makes me think that it should happen more is that you actually, it's in between Te Aumudu and Kihikihi, where you have your water and your sewage going right there. And I just think that it needs to go on hold. I know you've talked to a lot of people, but we really, really need to reconsider whether we're putting this amount of land into large lot residential.

speaker: lizstolwyk

text: Yeah, so when Council adopted its district plan, it was mindful that it was stopping down or preventing a whole lot of rural residential subdivision in the greater rural area. And so decided to focus those people who wanted large lot residential into enclaves where we could provide services like refuse collection and  the trickle feed water supplies. So we effectively adopted a compromise where we said no more rural residential subdivision out in the elite soils and let's focus this development into enclaves. Now, I understand what you're saying when you say Graham, that there is no commentary on the fact that this is all large lot residential, but effectively that all happened when the district plan was put into effect.  All that we're seeking today is for approval that the structure plan that is where the roads go, how is the stormwater managed? How do we put all that in place to allow the development to occur? So, effectively, the district plan decision in relation to is this large lot residential or not was made when we adopted the district plan.
